PURPOSE
Information security standard policies identify and describe the related technical and operational controls necessary to maintain the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of PeaceHealth's information technology environment.
DEFINITIONS
•
Caregiver: PeaceHealth employee, volunteer, trainee, and other persons whose conduct, in the performance of work for PeaceHealth, is under the direct control of PeaceHealth, regardless of whether they are paid by PeaceHealth.
POLICY
PeaceHealth will implement the processes and tools necessary to track/control/prevent/correct secure access to critical assets (e.g., information, resources, systems) according to the formal determination of which persons, computers, and applications have a need and right to access these critical assets based on an approved classification.
This is achieved by PeaceHealth implementing the following security controls:
1.
Segment the Network Based on Sensitivity. Segment the network based on the label or classification level of the information stored on the servers, locate all sensitive information on separated Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs)
2.
Enable Firewall Filtering between VLANs. Enable firewall filtering between VLANs to ensure that only authorized systems are able to communicate with other systems necessary to fulfill their specific responsibilities.
3.
Disable Workstation-to-Workstation Communication. Disable all workstation-to-workstation communication to limit an attacker's ability to move laterally and compromise neighboring systems, through technologies such as private VLANs or micro segmentation.
4.
Protect All Sensitive Information in Transit. Encrypt sensitive information in transit when feasible. Monitor the movement of data across network boundaries utilizing a data loss prevention solution to detect data exfiltration attempts and suspicious activities.
5.
Utilize an Active Discovery Tool to Identify Sensitive Data. Utilize an active discovery tool to identify all sensitive information stored, processed, or transmitted by the organization's technology systems, including those located on-site or at a remote service provider, and update the sensitive information inventory.
6.
Protect Information through Access Control Lists. Protect all information stored on systems with file system, network share, claims, application, or database specific access control lists. These controls will enforce the principle that only authorized individuals should have access to the information based on their need to access the information as a part of their responsibilities.
7.
Enforce Access Control to Data through Automated Tools. Use an automated tool, such as host-based Data Loss Prevention, to enforce access controls to data even when the data is copied off a system.
8.
Protect Sensitive Information at Rest. Encrypt all sensitive information at rest. Use encryption that requires secondary authentication in order to access the information when feasible. Implement full-disk encryption on mobile devices that store sensitive information.
9.
Enforce Detail Logging for Access or Changes to Sensitive Data. Enforce detailed audit logging for access to sensitive data or changes to sensitive data (utilizing tools such as File Integrity Monitoring or Security Information and Event Monitoring).
COMPLIANCE
Individuals included in the scope of this policy are required to comply with the policy and all associated policies and procedures. Violations are subject to removal of access and/or corrective action, up to and including termination of employment or other business relationship with PeaceHealth. Any deviations from security policies observed must be communicated to Information Security immediately upon discovery. If a security policy or control exception is necessary, it must be submitted in accordance with the Information Security Exceptions Policy.
